title: Erdős Problem #836: Intersecting 3-Chromatic Hypergraphs
description: For r-uniform hypergraphs with chromatic number 3 where any two edges intersect: Must there be O(r²) vertices? Must two edges meet in ≫r vertices?

meta.author: Paul Erdős, Saharon Shelah, Noga Alon, László Lovász

overview.historicalContext: This problem of Erdős and Shelah concerns the structure of r-uniform, intersecting, 3-chromatic hypergraphs. Erdős-Lovász (1975) proved the edge intersection bound. Alon later provided a counterexample showing exponentially many vertices are possible, disproving the O(r²) conjecture.
overview.problemStatement: Let r ≥ 2 and G be an r-uniform hypergraph with chromatic number 3 where any two edges intersect. Q1: Must G have O(r²) vertices? Q2: Must two edges meet in ≫r vertices?
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization defines hypergraphs, uniformity, intersection, and chromatic number. Question 1 is shown false via Alon's counterexample with ~4^r/√r vertices. Question 2 has partial answer: Erdős-Lovász proved ≫r/log r intersection.
keyInsights: Q1 is FALSE: Alon's counterexample has ~4^r/√r vertices
Q2 is PARTIAL: Erdős-Lovász proved two edges meet in ≫r/log r vertices
Fano plane is extremal: 3-uniform, no two edges share r-1 vertices
2-chromatic intersecting implies star (all edges share one vertex)

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #836 is SOLVED. Question 1 (O(r²) vertices) is FALSE - Alon's counterexample has exponentially many vertices. Question 2 (large edge intersection) has partial answer: Erdős-Lovász proved two edges meet in Ω(r/log r) vertices.
conclusion.implications: This shows 3-chromatic intersecting hypergraphs can be much larger than expected. The Fano plane remains a key extremal example for understanding the structure.
openQuestions: Can the r/log r bound be improved to r?
Are there other examples besides Fano where no two edges share r-1 vertices?
What is the exact growth rate of maximum vertex count?
